text: hi this is Seema and I am back with a
new lesson on confusing word pairs well
there are some words in English you know
where you feel like the meaning of those
words are kind of the same and you try
to use them in the same sentence but
guess what
these words are quite confusing because
their meanings are quite different
though they may sound quite similar
while saying it okay so what are they
now the first word pair is the words
deny and the word refuse well both these
words kind of sound like you know they
may have the same meaning right you're
wrong they don't have the same meaning
because deny what does it mean deny
basically means to say that something
isn't true or deny can also be used to
say that you didn't do something that
you did not do something okay or you can
say you did not do something let's put
that in an example or a sentence okay so
I can say that
Susan denied speaking bad about her
friend or gossiping about her friend so
what I'm saying is that Susan said that
she did not do it she did not gossip
about her friend
so Susan denied gossiping about her
friend or you can say that mr. Jones
denied the false claims of murder so he
is saying that the claims of modern stim
is not true that's what deny mean that
means that you say that a particular
things that about you is not true or
that you have not done something
now refuse well the meaning of refuse is
completely different from the word deny
how well the refuse basically means to
say firmly that you will not do
something so in other words and it is
basically a firm no when I say no so I
can say that the little boy refused to
eat his dinner he firmly said that he
will not do it he will not eat it I can
say that mr. Joshi was fired because he
refused to obey his boss he refused to
do what he was asked to do okay so you
can see that both these words are quite
confusing but but very very different
meanings yeah okay the next one is staff
and employees okay
bow these words again sounding very
similar but again quite different
meanings okay
stuff refers to an uncountable thing or
shall I say an uncountable noun and it
is always in the singular it basically
refers to a group of workers working in
an organization so it's a group of
workers but that group is in a singular
because we are taking it as one whole
group so there may be a group of a
hundred workers but that's one group it
is singular and uncountable on the other
hand an employee or an employee's are
also people who work in an organization
but we are referring to the plural and a
countable noun
and when I talk about employees I'm
talking about individual employees which
you can count because as I mentioned
they are countable right so I can say
that there are 100 employees working in
the organization it's plural you can
count the individual number of workers
right but I have to say that the staff
strength is 100 I don't say that there
are 100 stops I can say that there are
100 employees but I cannot say that
there are 100 stops I have to say that
there are there is a staff there is a
staff of 100 employees or 100 people
right the next one is interfere versus
the confusing pair which is intervene oh
my god both of them sounds so similar
and kind of feel like they are similar
in meaning but no interfere basically is
a negative word a negative word to say
that something is coming in between or a
negative thing to denote that something
is in between and you don't want it to
come in between ok intervene also means
that something is coming in between but
this has a more positive vibe to it ok
let's see how ok which means you can't
use both these words in a sentence
together they're two different words
altogether ok so I can say that my
mother-in-law always interferes in my in
my household Affairs now there is a
negative you know vibe to this sentence
because my mother-in-law is coming in
between when I don't want her to come in
between right so that's a negative thing
ok but intervene ok I can say that
Joe's mother intervened when he had a
drug addiction problem so Joe was going
through a drug addiction problem which
he couldn't you know take care of
because he was addicted to drugs but his
mother came in between now was that a
positive thing to do yes his mother came
in between and helped him through it
right so interfere and intervene are
different because even though both
things mean that you are coming in the
middle of something you are coming in
between something interfere is negative
and intervene is a very positive thing
yeah and the next one is problem and
trouble this is very simple problem is
something that is accountable you can
count problems okay so as a problem
would be two problems three problems ten
problems or a hundred problems okay
trouble is uncountable
so both words basically means that they
are a type of worry you know you're
worried about something you've got a
problem you're worried you have some
trouble you're worried but the only
difference in using it in a sentence is
that when I'm referring to something
that is countable I can say I've got
three problems with this handset or with
my phone my phone freezes problem number
one my phone won't charge properly
problem number two my phone turns off
you know without any warning three
problems okay but if I want to talk
about something that is uncountable I
can say I've got trouble with my handset
I've got three problems with my handset
I've got trouble with my handset because
problem is countable you can count them
but a trouble trouble is non countable
it is uncountable so to speak right the
next one is suppose as opposed to
supposed to well a lot of people make a
very very common error in this in using
both these words when I just use the
word suppose the meaning can either be
to expect or think or believe or shall I
say to imagine Wow this word has got
four different meanings okay so I can
say I suppose Mary will not answer the
phone this late at night which means I'm
saying I expect that she will not answer
her phone
I think that she will not answer her
phone I believe that she will not answer
her phone or I imagine that she will not
answer her phone but when I say supposed
to what does that mean supposed to
basically means when I'm trying to say
that something should be done so I can
tell my friend you are supposed to study
at least two months before your
examinations if you want to you know get
an A so he's supposed to do it so
something which is studying in this case
should be done I can see you are
supposed to drive slowly if you want to
avoid getting into an accident supposed
to meaning something should be done it
is something that you just have to do
right so that's the difference between
suppose and suppose to now the next and
the lost pair I won't confuse you
anymore is change and to switch okay
again quite similar sounding but no you
can't use them together in one sentence
okay so change basically means to become
different okay become different so I can
say that the weather is changing okay so
now we we had summer now the weather is
changing the leaves are falling it's
gonna it's gonna get cold so it's going
to be a winter now or maybe autumn so
with
thing becomes different with a change
right as opposed to that a switch switch
basically means that you stop doing or
shall I say using something and then you
start doing or using something else
right so you were doing something or you
were using something you've stopped
doing that or using that all of a sudden
and then you've quickly started doing or
using something else so I can say
something like I switched from using an
Android phone to an iPhone which means I
may have been using an Android phone for
six months and then I don't like it so I
